Convex Optimization(4): Unconstrained Optimization
å‘è¡¨äº 2021-05-27| æ›´æ–°äº 2021-05-27|Course Notes
é˜…è¯»é‡:

I am taking Convex Optimization this semester (2021 Spring). The notes are based on my understanding of the course materials provided by Prof. Zhouchen Lin. The notes only offer concise definition and formulas with few proofs and examples.

From this chapter, we start to introduce convex optimization algorithms, including descent methods, newtonâ€™s methods, conjugate direction methods, and majorization minimization. I used to consider gradient descent as the simple basis of neural networks, so I did not pay much attention to it. But it turns out that the underlying theory can be rather complex. I feel like learning the history and construction of nowadays neural networks. Theory is fascinating in this way.

Descent methods#

x(k+1)=x(k)+t(k)Î”x(k)\mathbf{x}^{(k+1)} = \mathbf{x}^{(k)}+\mathbf{t}^{(k)}\Delta\mathbf{x}^{(k)} x(k+1)=x(k)+t(k)Î”x(k)

Steepest descent method#

The first-order Taylor approximation of f(x+v)f(\mathbf{x}+\mathbf{v})f(x+v) is

f(x+v)â‰ˆf(x)+âˆ‡f(x)âŠ¤vf(\mathbf{x}+\mathbf{v}) \approx f(\mathbf{x})+\nabla f(\mathbf{x})^\top \mathbf{v} f(x+v)â‰ˆf(x)+âˆ‡f(x)âŠ¤v

The second term can be interpreted as a directional derivative in the direction vvv. Our goal is to choose a step direction vvv such that the derivative is as negative as possible.

We define a normalized steepest descent direction as

Î”xnsd=argâ¡minâ¡v{âˆ‡f(x)âŠ¤vâˆ£âˆ¥vâˆ¥=1}\Delta\mathbf{x}_{nsd}={\arg\min}_\mathbf{v}\{\nabla f(\mathbf{x})^\top \mathbf{v}\mid \|\mathbf{v}\|=1 \} Î”xnsdâ€‹=argminvâ€‹{âˆ‡f(x)âŠ¤vâˆ£âˆ¥vâˆ¥=1}

We can define an unnormalized steepest descent by dual norm

Î”xsd=âˆ¥âˆ‡f(x)âˆ¥âˆ—Î”xnsd\Delta\mathbf{x}_{sd}=\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x})\|_*\Delta\mathbf{x}_{nsd} Î”xsdâ€‹=âˆ¥âˆ‡f(x)âˆ¥âˆ—â€‹Î”xnsdâ€‹

This search direction satisfies

âˆ‡f(x)âŠ¤Î”xsd=âˆ¥âˆ‡f(x)âˆ¥âˆ—âˆ‡f(x)âŠ¤Î”xnsd=âˆ’âˆ¥âˆ‡f(x)âˆ¥âˆ—2\nabla f(\mathbf{x})^\top \Delta\mathbf{x}_{sd}=\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x})\|_*\nabla f(\mathbf{x})^\top \Delta\mathbf{x}_{nsd} = -\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x})\|_*^2 âˆ‡f(x)âŠ¤Î”xsdâ€‹=âˆ¥âˆ‡f(x)âˆ¥âˆ—â€‹âˆ‡f(x)âŠ¤Î”xnsdâ€‹=âˆ’âˆ¥âˆ‡f(x)âˆ¥âˆ—2â€‹

  • Euclidean norm case

    When âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥\|\cdot\|âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥ is Euclidean norm, Î”xnsd=âˆ’âˆ‡f(x)âˆ¥âˆ‡f(x)âˆ¥\Delta\mathbf{x}_{nsd} =- \frac{\nabla f(\mathbf{x})}{\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x})\|}Î”xnsdâ€‹=âˆ’âˆ¥âˆ‡f(x)âˆ¥âˆ‡f(x)â€‹, and Î”xsd=âˆ’âˆ‡f(x)\Delta\mathbf{x}_{sd} =- \nabla f(\mathbf{x})Î”xsdâ€‹=âˆ’âˆ‡f(x), which is exactly the gradient descent method.

    The dual norm is âˆ¥zâˆ¥âˆ—=âˆ¥Pâˆ’1/2zâˆ¥2\|\mathbf{z}\|_*=\|\mathbf{P}^{-1/2}\mathbf{z}\|_2âˆ¥zâˆ¥âˆ—â€‹=âˆ¥Pâˆ’1/2zâˆ¥2â€‹, so the steepest descent step is

    Î”xsd=âˆ’Pâˆ’1âˆ‡f(x)\Delta\mathbf{x}_{sd}=-\mathbf{P}^{-1}\nabla f(\mathbf{x}) Î”xsdâ€‹=âˆ’Pâˆ’1âˆ‡f(x)

  • Coordinate change

    Î”xË‰=âˆ’âˆ‡fË‰(xË‰)=âˆ’Pâˆ’1/2âˆ‡f(Pâˆ’1/2xË‰)=âˆ’Pâˆ’1/2âˆ‡f(x)\Delta\bar{\mathbf{x}} = -\nabla \bar{f}(\bar{\mathbf{x}} )=-\mathbf{P}^{-1/2}\nabla f(\mathbf{P}^{-1/2}\bar{\mathbf{x}}) = -\mathbf{P}^{-1/2}\nabla f({\mathbf{x}}) Î”xË‰=âˆ’âˆ‡fË‰â€‹(xË‰)=âˆ’Pâˆ’1/2âˆ‡f(Pâˆ’1/2xË‰)=âˆ’Pâˆ’1/2âˆ‡f(x)

    Hence, the normalized steepest descent direction is always the coordinate axis direction whose decrease in fff is greatest.

  • Choice of norm

    If we already know an approximation H^\hat{\mathbf{H}}H^ of the Hessian at the optimal point, then we can choose P=H^\mathbf{P} = \hat{\mathbf{H}}P=H^, so that the Hessian of fË‰\bar{f}fË‰â€‹ would be

    âˆ‡2fË‰(xË‰)=âˆ‡2f(Pâˆ’1/2xË‰)=H^âˆ’1/2âˆ‡2f(xË‰)H^âˆ’1/2â‰ˆI\nabla^2\bar{f}(\bar{\mathbf{x}}) = \nabla ^2f(\mathbf{P}^{-1/2}\bar{\mathbf{x}})=\hat{\mathbf{H}}^{-1/2}\nabla ^2f(\bar{\mathbf{x}})\hat{\mathbf{H}}^{-1/2}\approx \mathbf{I} âˆ‡2fË‰â€‹(xË‰)=âˆ‡2f(Pâˆ’1/2xË‰)=H^âˆ’1/2âˆ‡2f(xË‰)H^âˆ’1/2â‰ˆI

    Thus, the condition number is likely to be low.

    Geometrically saying, the ellipsoid {xâˆ£âˆ¥xâˆ¥Pâ‰¤1}\{\mathbf{x}\mid\|\mathbf{x}\|_\mathbf{P}\le 1 \}{xâˆ£âˆ¥xâˆ¥Pâ€‹â‰¤1} should approximate the shape of the sub level set({xâˆ£f(x)â‰¤L}\{\mathbf{x}\mid f(\mathbf{x})\le L \}{xâˆ£f(x)â‰¤L}).

    In the following image, the left ellipsoid is similar to the sub level set, while the right one is not.

    If the condition number of a set is small, it means that the set has approximately the same width in all directions, i.e., it is nearly spherical.

    Clearly the left sub level set is more likely a sphere.

Newtonâ€™s method#

Motivation. Steepest descent only use the first derivatives, try to use higher derivatives.

Method#

Construct a quadratic approximation to the objective function that matches the 1st and 2nd derivative values at that point. Then minimize the approximate function.

f(x)â‰ˆf(x(k))+g(k)âŠ¤(xâˆ’x(k))+12(xâˆ’x(k))âŠ¤F(x(k))(xâˆ’x(k))â‰œq(x)f(\mathbf{x}) \approx f\left(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}\right)+\mathbf{g}^{(k) \top}\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{(k)}\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{(k)}\right)^{\top} \mathbf{F}\left(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}\right)\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{(k)}\right) \triangleq q(\mathbf{x}) f(x)â‰ˆf(x(k))+g(k)âŠ¤(xâˆ’x(k))+21â€‹(xâˆ’x(k))âŠ¤F(x(k))(xâˆ’x(k))â‰œq(x)

Here, g(k)=âˆ‡f(x(k))\mathbf{g}^{(k)}=\nabla f\left(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}\right)g(k)=âˆ‡f(x(k)).

Applying the First-Order Necessary Condition (FONC) to qqq yields

0=âˆ‡q(x)=g(k)+F(x(k))(xâˆ’x(k))\mathbf{0}=\nabla q(\mathbf{x})=\mathbf{g}^{(k)}+\mathbf{F}\left(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}\right)\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{(k)}\right) 0=âˆ‡q(x)=g(k)+F(x(k))(xâˆ’x(k))

If F(x(k))â‰»0\mathbf{F}\left(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}\right) \succ 0F(x(k))â‰»0, then qqq achieves a minimum at

x(k+1)=x(k)âˆ’F(x(k))âˆ’1g(k)\mathbf{x}^{(k+1)}=\mathbf{x}^{(k)}-\mathbf{F}\left(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{g}^{(k)} x(k+1)=x(k)âˆ’F(x(k))âˆ’1g(k)

The above is the recursive updating function of Newtonâ€™s method.

Analysis#

Cons:

  1. If F(x(k))\mathbf{F}\left(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}\right)F(x(k)) is not positive definite, the algorithm might not head in the direction of decreasing values of the objective function.
  2. Even if it is positive definite, it might occur that $ f\left(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}\right)\le f\left(\mathbf{x}^{(k+1)}\right)$, e.g. if starting point is far away from xâˆ—\mathbf{x}^*xâˆ—.

Pros:

  1. When starting point is near xâˆ—\mathbf{x}^*xâˆ—, Newtonâ€™s method converges to xâˆ—\mathbf{x}^*xâˆ— with order of convergence at least 2.

    Note that we only need to assume fâˆˆC3,âˆ‡f(xâˆ—)=0,F(xâˆ—)f\in C^3, \nabla f(\mathbf{x}^*)=\mathbf{0},\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{x}^*)fâˆˆC3,âˆ‡f(xâˆ—)=0,F(xâˆ—), is invertible. So Newtonâ€™s method does not necessarily converge to a local minimum.

  2. Descent property ($ f\left(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}\right)\ge f\left(\mathbf{x}^{(k+1)}\right)$) holds true with a little modification to the algorithm(Damped Newtonâ€™s Method).

    If F(x(k))â‰»0,g(k)=âˆ‡f(x(k))â‰ 0\mathbf{F}\left(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}\right) \succ 0, \mathbf{g}^{(k)}=\nabla f\left(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}\right)\ne 0F(x(k))â‰»0,g(k)=âˆ‡f(x(k))î€ =0, then the direction

    d(k)=âˆ’F(x(k))âˆ’1g(k)=x(k+1)âˆ’x(k)\mathbf{d}^{(k)}=-\mathbf{F}\left(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{g}^{(k)}=\mathbf{x}^{(k+1)}-\mathbf{x}^{(k)} d(k)=âˆ’F(x(k))âˆ’1g(k)=x(k+1)âˆ’x(k)

    is a descent direction in the sense that âˆƒÎ±^>0,âˆ€Î±âˆˆ(0,Î±^)\exist\hat{\alpha}>0,\forall\alpha\in(0,\hat{\alpha})âˆƒÎ±^>0,âˆ€Î±âˆˆ(0,Î±^),

    f(x(k)+Î±d(k))<f(x(k))f(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}+\alpha \mathbf{d}^{(k)})<f(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}) f(x(k)+Î±d(k))<f(x(k))

    Proof. Let

    Ï•(Î±)=f(x(k)+Î±d(k))\phi(\alpha ) =f(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}+\alpha \mathbf{d}^{(k)}) Ï•(Î±)=f(x(k)+Î±d(k))

    Thus, we need to prove that âˆƒÎ±^>0,âˆ€Î±âˆˆ(0,Î±^)\exist\hat{\alpha}>0,\forall\alpha\in(0,\hat{\alpha})âˆƒÎ±^>0,âˆ€Î±âˆˆ(0,Î±^), Ï•(Î±)<Ï•(0)\phi(\alpha)<\phi(0)Ï•(Î±)<Ï•(0). Given F(x(k))âˆ’1â‰»0\mathbf{F}\left(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}\right)^{-1} \succ 0F(x(k))âˆ’1â‰»0,

    Ï•â€²(Î±)=âˆ‡f(x(k)+Î±d(k))âŠ¤d(k)Ï•â€²(0)=âˆ‡f(x(k))âŠ¤d(k)=âˆ’g(k)F(x(k))âˆ’1g(k)<0\phi'(\alpha ) =\nabla f(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}+\alpha \mathbf{d}^{(k)})^\top \mathbf{d}^{(k)}\\ \phi'(0 ) =\nabla f(\mathbf{x}^{(k)})^\top \mathbf{d}^{(k)} =-\mathbf{g}^{(k)}\mathbf{F}\left(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{g}^{(k)}<0 Ï•â€²(Î±)=âˆ‡f(x(k)+Î±d(k))âŠ¤d(k)Ï•â€²(0)=âˆ‡f(x(k))âŠ¤d(k)=âˆ’g(k)F(x(k))âˆ’1g(k)<0

    Hence, there must exist an Î±^\hat{\alpha}Î±^ satisfies Ï•(Î±)<Ï•(0)\phi(\alpha)<\phi(0)Ï•(Î±)<Ï•(0).

Damped Newtonâ€™s method#

Modify the recursive updating function with a parameter Î±k\alpha_kÎ±kâ€‹ to ensure descent property:

x(k+1)=x(k)âˆ’Î±kF(x(k))âˆ’1g(k)Î±k=argâ¡minâ¡Î±â‰¥0f(x(k)âˆ’Î±kF(x(k))âˆ’1g(k))\mathbf{x}^{(k+1)}=\mathbf{x}^{(k)}-\alpha_k\mathbf{F}\left(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{g}^{(k)}\\ \alpha_k = \arg\min_{\alpha\ge 0} f(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}-\alpha_k\mathbf{F}\left(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{g}^{(k)}) x(k+1)=x(k)âˆ’Î±kâ€‹F(x(k))âˆ’1g(k)Î±kâ€‹=argÎ±â‰¥0minâ€‹f(x(k)âˆ’Î±kâ€‹F(x(k))âˆ’1g(k))

Drawback: Computing F(x(k))\mathbf{F}\left(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}\right)F(x(k)) and solving F(x(k))d(k)=âˆ’g(k)\mathbf{F}\left(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}\right)\mathbf{d}^{(k)}=-\mathbf{g}^{(k)}F(x(k))d(k)=âˆ’g(k) are computationally expensive.

Levenberg-Marquardt modification#

To ensure descent property when the Hessian matrix is not positive definite, modify the recursive updating function as:

x(k+1)=x(k)âˆ’Î±k(F(x(k))+Î¼kI)âˆ’1g(k),Î¼kâ‰¥0\mathbf{x}^{(k+1)}=\mathbf{x}^{(k)}-\alpha_k\left(\mathbf{F}\left(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}\right)+\mu_k\mathbf{I}\right) ^{-1}\mathbf{g}^{(k)},\quad\mu_k\ge 0 x(k+1)=x(k)âˆ’Î±kâ€‹(F(x(k))+Î¼kâ€‹I)âˆ’1g(k),Î¼kâ€‹â‰¥0

The algorithm is actually locally minimizing

f(x)+Î¼k2âˆ¥xâˆ’x(k)âˆ¥2f(\mathbf{x})+\frac{\mu_k}{2}\|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{(k)}\|^2 f(x)+2Î¼kâ€‹â€‹âˆ¥xâˆ’x(k)âˆ¥2

When Î¼kâ†’0\mu_k\to 0Î¼kâ€‹â†’0, it becomes pure Newtonâ€™s method. When Î¼kâ†’âˆ\mu_k\to\inftyÎ¼kâ€‹â†’âˆ, it becomes pure gradient descent method with small step size. In practice, start from a small Î¼k\mu_kÎ¼kâ€‹ and increase it until descent property is satisfied.

Case: Nonlinear least-squares#

minâ¡xâˆ‘i=1m(ri(x))2\min_\mathbf{x}\sum_{i=1}^m \left(r_i(\mathbf{x}) \right)^2 xminâ€‹i=1âˆ‘mâ€‹(riâ€‹(x))2

âˆ‘i=1mri(x)âˆ‚2riâˆ‚xkâˆ‚xj(x)\sum_{i=1}^{m} r_{i}(\mathbf{x}) \frac{\partial^{2} r_{i}}{\partial x_{k} \partial x_{j}}(\mathbf{x}) i=1âˆ‘mâ€‹riâ€‹(x)âˆ‚xkâ€‹âˆ‚xjâ€‹âˆ‚2riâ€‹â€‹(x)

x(k+1)=x(k)âˆ’(J(x)TJ(x)+S(x))âˆ’1J(x)Tr(x)\mathbf{x}^{(k+1)}=\mathbf{x}^{(k)}-\left(\mathbf{J}(\mathbf{x})^{T} \mathbf{J}(\mathbf{x})+\mathbf{S}(\mathbf{x})\right)^{-1} \mathbf{J}(\mathbf{x})^{T} \mathbf{r}(\mathbf{x}) x(k+1)=x(k)âˆ’(J(x)TJ(x)+S(x))âˆ’1J(x)Tr(x)

Conjugate direction methods#

Motivation. Intermediate between steepest descent and Newtonâ€™s method.

  1. Solve quadratics of nnn variables in nnn steps.
  2. Requires no Hessian.
  3. No matrix inversion, no storage of nÃ—nn\times nnÃ—n matrix required.

QQQ-conjugate: QQQ is a real symmetric nÃ—nn\times nnÃ—n matrix. Directions d(0),d(1),â‹¯â€‰,d(m)\mathbf{d}^{(0)},\mathbf{d}^{(1)},\cdots,\mathbf{d}^{(m)}d(0),d(1),â‹¯,d(m) are QQQ-conjugate if âˆ€iâ‰ j\forall i\ne jâˆ€iî€ =j, d(i)âŠ¤Qd(j)=0\mathbf{d}^{(i)\top} Q \mathbf{d}^{(j)}=0d(i)âŠ¤Qd(j)=0.

Lemma. If Qâ‰»0Q\succ\mathbf{0}Qâ‰»0 and directions d(0),d(1),â‹¯â€‰,d(k),kâ‰¤nâˆ’1\mathbf{d}^{(0)},\mathbf{d}^{(1)},\cdots,\mathbf{d}^{(k)},k\le n-1d(0),d(1),â‹¯,d(k),kâ‰¤nâˆ’1 are nonzero and QQQ-conjugate, then they are linearly independent.

Direction#

Lemma. By mathematical induction, we have

ğŸŒŸDirections.

Non-quadratic problems#

Motivation. Consider the quadratic function f(x)=12xTQxâˆ’xTbf(\mathbf{x})=\frac{1}{2} \mathbf{x}^{T} \mathbf{Q} \mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{T} \mathbf{b}f(x)=21â€‹xTQxâˆ’xTb as a second-order Taylor series approximation of any objective function. Thus, Q\mathbf{Q}Q is the Hessian that needs reevaluation at each iteration.

To be Hessian-free, modify the method of computing Î±k,Î²k\alpha_k, \beta_kÎ±kâ€‹,Î²kâ€‹:

Î±k=argâ¡minâ¡Î±>0f(x(k)+Î±d(k))\alpha_k=\arg\min_{\alpha>0} f(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}+\alpha\mathbf{d}^{(k)})Î±kâ€‹=argminÎ±>0â€‹f(x(k)+Î±d(k)) can be replaced by a linear search.

Replace Qd(k)\mathbf{Q}\mathbf{d}^{(k)}Qd(k) in Î²k\beta_kÎ²kâ€‹ with g(k+1)âˆ’g(k)Î±k\frac{\mathbf{g}^{(k+1) }-\mathbf{g}^{(k)} }{\alpha_k}Î±kâ€‹g(k+1)âˆ’g(k)â€‹:

Î²k=g(k+1)âŠ¤Qd(k)d(k)âŠ¤Qd(k)=g(k+1)âŠ¤[g(k+1)âˆ’g(k)]d(k)âŠ¤[g(k+1)âˆ’g(k)](Hestenes-StiefelÂ formula)=g(k+1)âŠ¤[g(k+1)âˆ’g(k)]g(k)âŠ¤g(k)(Polak-RibiereÂ formula)=g(k+1)âŠ¤g(k+1)g(k)âŠ¤g(k)(Fletcher-ReevesÂ formula)\begin{aligned} \beta_{k} =&\frac{\mathbf{g}^{(k+1) \top} \mathbf{Q}\mathbf{d}^{(k)}}{\mathbf{d}^{(k) \top} \mathbf{Q} \mathbf{d}^{(k)}}\\ =&\frac{\mathbf{g}^{(k+1) \top} [\mathbf{g}^{(k+1) }-\mathbf{g}^{(k)}]}{\mathbf{d}^{(k) \top}[\mathbf{g}^{(k+1) }-\mathbf{g}^{(k)}]}\quad\text{(Hestenes-Stiefel formula)}\\ =&\frac{\mathbf{g}^{(k+1) \top} [\mathbf{g}^{(k+1) }-\mathbf{g}^{(k)}]}{\mathbf{g}^{(k)\top}\mathbf{g}^{(k)}}\quad\text{(Polak-Ribiere formula)}\\ =&\frac{\mathbf{g}^{(k+1) \top} \mathbf{g}^{(k+1) }}{\mathbf{g}^{(k)\top}\mathbf{g}^{(k)}}\quad\text{(Fletcher-Reeves formula)} \end{aligned} Î²kâ€‹====â€‹d(k)âŠ¤Qd(k)g(k+1)âŠ¤Qd(k)â€‹d(k)âŠ¤[g(k+1)âˆ’g(k)]g(k+1)âŠ¤[g(k+1)âˆ’g(k)]â€‹(Hestenes-StiefelÂ formula)g(k)âŠ¤g(k)g(k+1)âŠ¤[g(k+1)âˆ’g(k)]â€‹(Polak-RibiereÂ formula)g(k)âŠ¤g(k)g(k+1)âŠ¤g(k+1)â€‹(Fletcher-ReevesÂ formula)â€‹

The last equation is derived from the lemma above and definition of d(k)\mathbf{d}^{(k)}d(k).

  1. Non-quadratic problems might not converge in nnn steps, so reinitialize the direction vector to the negative gradient after every few iterations (e.g., nnn or n+1n + 1n+1).
  2. If line search of Î±\alphaÎ± is inaccurate, HS formula is better. Choice of formula depends on objective function.

Motivation. To avoid computing F(x(k))âˆ’1\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{x}^{(k)})^{-1}F(x(k))âˆ’1 in damped Newtonâ€™s method, try replace it with an approximation.

Hk+1Î”g(i)=Î”x(i),0â‰¤iâ‰¤k\mathbf{H}_{k+1}\Delta\mathbf{g}^{(i)}=\Delta\mathbf{x}^{(i)},0\le i\le k Hk+1â€‹Î”g(i)=Î”x(i),0â‰¤iâ‰¤k

    We know from the first equation that Î”x(k)âˆ’HkÎ”g(k)=(akz(k)âŠ¤Î”g(k))z(k)\Delta \mathbf{x}^{(k)}-\mathbf{H}_{k} \Delta \mathbf{g}^{(k)}=\left(a_{k} \mathbf{z}^{(k) \top} \Delta \mathbf{g}^{(k)}\right) \mathbf{z}^{(k)}Î”x(k)âˆ’Hkâ€‹Î”g(k)=(akâ€‹z(k)âŠ¤Î”g(k))z(k), multiply it by Î”g(k)\Delta\mathbf{g}^{(k)}Î”g(k) to replace the denominator

    Algorithm. Start with k=0k=0k=0 and a real symmetric positive definite H0\mathbf{H}_0H0â€‹.

    2. Take Î±k=argâ¡minâ¡Î±â‰¥0f(x(k)+Î±d(k))\alpha_{k} =\arg\min_{\alpha\ge 0}f(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}+\alpha \mathbf{d}^{(k)})Î±kâ€‹=argminÎ±â‰¥0â€‹f(x(k)+Î±d(k)). Update x(k+1)=x(k)+Î±kd(k)\mathbf{x}^{(k+1)} =\mathbf{x}^{(k)}+\alpha_{k} \mathbf{d}^{(k)}x(k+1)=x(k)+Î±kâ€‹d(k).

      Î”x(k)=Î±kd(k)Î”g(k)=g(k+1)âˆ’g(k)Hk+1=Hk+(Î”x(k)âˆ’HkÎ”g(k))(Î”x(k)âˆ’HkÎ”g(k))âŠ¤Î”g(k)âŠ¤(Î”x(k)âˆ’HkÎ”g(k))\begin{aligned} \Delta \mathbf{x}^{(k)} &=\alpha_{k} \mathbf{d}^{(k)} \\ \Delta \mathbf{g}^{(k)} &=\mathbf{g}^{(k+1)}-\mathbf{g}^{(k)} \\ \mathbf{H}_{k+1} &=\mathbf{H}_{k}+\frac{\left(\Delta \mathbf{x}^{(k)}-\mathbf{H}_{k} \Delta \mathbf{g}^{(k)}\right)\left(\Delta \mathbf{x}^{(k)}-\mathbf{H}_{k} \Delta \mathbf{g}^{(k)}\right)^{\top}}{\Delta \mathbf{g}^{(k) \top}\left(\Delta \mathbf{x}^{(k)}-\mathbf{H}_{k} \Delta \mathbf{g}^{(k)}\right)} \end{aligned} Î”x(k)Î”g(k)Hk+1â€‹â€‹=Î±kâ€‹d(k)=g(k+1)âˆ’g(k)=Hkâ€‹+Î”g(k)âŠ¤(Î”x(k)âˆ’Hkâ€‹Î”g(k))(Î”x(k)âˆ’Hkâ€‹Î”g(k))(Î”x(k)âˆ’Hkâ€‹Î”g(k))âŠ¤â€‹â€‹

  2. Davidon-Fletcher-Powell (DFP) Algorithm

    Rank two update

    Algorithm. Start with k=0k=0k=0 and a real symmetric positive definite H0\mathbf{H}_0H0â€‹.

    1. If g(k)=0\mathbf{g}^{(k)}=0g(k)=0, stop, else set d(k)=âˆ’Hkg(k)\mathbf{d}^{(k)}=-\mathbf{H}_k\mathbf{g}^{(k)}d(k)=âˆ’Hkâ€‹g(k).

    2. Take Î±k=argâ¡minâ¡Î±â‰¥0f(x(k)+Î±d(k))\alpha_{k} =\arg\min_{\alpha\ge 0}f(\mathbf{x}^{(k)}+\alpha \mathbf{d}^{(k)})Î±kâ€‹=argminÎ±â‰¥0â€‹f(x(k)+Î±d(k)). Update x(k+1)=x(k)+Î±kd(k)\mathbf{x}^{(k+1)} =\mathbf{x}^{(k)}+\alpha_{k} \mathbf{d}^{(k)}x(k+1)=x(k)+Î±kâ€‹d(k).

    3. Compute gradient and the next inverse Hessian approximation, and return to step 1 with k:=k+1k:=k+1k:=k+1.

      Î”x(k)=Î±kd(k)Î”g(k)=g(k+1)âˆ’g(k)Hk+1=Hk+Î”x(k)Î”x(k)TÎ”x(k)TÎ”g(k)âˆ’[HkÎ”g(k)][HkÎ”g(k)]TÎ”g(k)THkÎ”g(k)\begin{aligned} \Delta \mathbf{x}^{(k)} &=\alpha_{k} \mathbf{d}^{(k)} \\ \Delta \mathbf{g}^{(k)} &=\mathbf{g}^{(k+1)}-\mathbf{g}^{(k)} \\ \mathbf{H}_{k+1} &=\mathbf{H}_{k}+\frac{\Delta \mathbf{x}^{(k)} \Delta \mathbf{x}^{(k) T}}{\Delta \mathbf{x}^{(k) T} \Delta \mathbf{g}^{(k)}}-\frac{\left[\mathbf{H}_{k} \Delta \mathbf{g}^{(k)}\right]\left[\mathbf{H}_{k} \Delta \mathbf{g}^{(k)}\right]^{T}}{\Delta \mathbf{g}^{(k) T} \mathbf{H}_{k} \Delta \mathbf{g}^{(k)}} \end{aligned} Î”x(k)Î”g(k)Hk+1â€‹â€‹=Î±kâ€‹d(k)=g(k+1)âˆ’g(k)=Hkâ€‹+Î”x(k)TÎ”g(k)Î”x(k)Î”x(k)Tâ€‹âˆ’Î”g(k)THkâ€‹Î”g(k)[Hkâ€‹Î”g(k)][Hkâ€‹Î”g(k)]Tâ€‹â€‹

  3. Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno (BFGS) Algorithm

    Note that we now approximate Qâˆ’1\mathbf{Q}^{-1}Qâˆ’1 by Hk\mathbf{H}_kHkâ€‹, we can also approximate Q\mathbf{Q}Q itself and take the inverse at last.

    Hk+1Î”g(i)=Î”x(i),0â‰¤iâ‰¤kBk+1Î”x(i)=Î”g(i),0â‰¤iâ‰¤k\mathbf{H}_{k+1} \Delta \mathbf{g}^{(i)}=\Delta \mathbf{x}^{(i)}, 0 \leq i \leq k\\ \mathbf{B}_{k+1} \Delta \mathbf{x}^{(i)}=\Delta \mathbf{g}^{(i)}, 0 \leq i \leq k Hk+1â€‹Î”g(i)=Î”x(i),0â‰¤iâ‰¤kBk+1â€‹Î”x(i)=Î”g(i),0â‰¤iâ‰¤k

    To obtain approximation of the inverse Hessian,

    Hk+1=(Bk+1)âˆ’1=(Bk+Î”g(k)Î”g(k)TÎ”g(k)TÎ”x(k)âˆ’[BkÎ”x(k)][BkÎ”x(k)]TÎ”x(k)TBkÎ”x(k))âˆ’1\mathbf{H}_{k+1} = (\mathbf{B}_{k+1})^{-1} =\left(\mathbf{B}_{k}+\frac{\Delta \mathbf{g}^{(k)} \Delta \mathbf{g}^{(k) T}}{\Delta \mathbf{g}^{(k) T} \Delta \mathbf{x}^{(k)}}-\frac{\left[\mathbf{B}_{k} \Delta \mathbf{x}^{(k)}\right]\left[\mathbf{B}_{k} \Delta \mathbf{x}^{(k)}\right]^{T}}{\Delta \mathbf{x}^{(k) T} \mathbf{B}_{k} \Delta \mathbf{x}^{(k)}}\right)^{-1} Hk+1â€‹=(Bk+1â€‹)âˆ’1=(Bkâ€‹+Î”g(k)TÎ”x(k)Î”g(k)Î”g(k)Tâ€‹âˆ’Î”x(k)TBkâ€‹Î”x(k)[Bkâ€‹Î”x(k)][Bkâ€‹Î”x(k)]Tâ€‹)âˆ’1

    Where A,C\mathbf{A},\mathbf{C}A,C are invertible and the size of U,C,V\mathbf{U},\mathbf{C},\mathbf{V}U,C,V are compatible.

    Hence, the updating of H\mathbf{H}H is

    Hk+1BFGS=Hk+(1+Î”g(k)âŠ¤HkÎ”g(k)Î”g(k)âŠ¤Î”x(k))Î”x(k)Î”x(k)âŠ¤Î”x(k)âŠ¤Î”g(k)âˆ’HkÎ”g(k)Î”x(k)âŠ¤+(HkÎ”g(k)Î”x(k)âŠ¤)âŠ¤Î”g(k)âŠ¤Î”x(k)\mathbf{H}_{k+1}^{B F G S}=\mathbf{H}_{k}+\left(1+\frac{\Delta \mathbf{g}^{(k) \top} \mathbf{H}_{k} \Delta \mathbf{g}^{(k)}}{\Delta \mathbf{g}^{(k) \top} \Delta \mathbf{x}^{(k)}}\right) \frac{\Delta \mathbf{x}^{(k)} \Delta \mathbf{x}^{(k) \top}}{\Delta \mathbf{x}^{(k) \top} \Delta \mathbf{g}^{(k)}}-\frac{\mathbf{H}_{k} \Delta \mathbf{g}^{(k)} \Delta \mathbf{x}^{(k) \top}+\left(\mathbf{H}_{k} \Delta \mathbf{g}^{(k)} \Delta \mathbf{x}^{(k) \top}\right)^{\top}}{\Delta \mathbf{g}^{(k) \top} \Delta \mathbf{x}^{(k)}} Hk+1BFGSâ€‹=Hkâ€‹+(1+Î”g(k)âŠ¤Î”x(k)Î”g(k)âŠ¤Hkâ€‹Î”g(k)â€‹)Î”x(k)âŠ¤Î”g(k)Î”x(k)Î”x(k)âŠ¤â€‹âˆ’Î”g(k)âŠ¤Î”x(k)Hkâ€‹Î”g(k)Î”x(k)âŠ¤+(Hkâ€‹Î”g(k)Î”x(k)âŠ¤)âŠ¤â€‹

Majorization minimization#

Basic framework#

Original problem:

minâ¡xf(x)s.t.xâˆˆC\min_\mathbf{x} f(\mathbf{x})\quad s.t. \mathbf{x}\in C xminâ€‹f(x)s.t.xâˆˆC

New problem:

minâ¡xg(x)s.t.xâˆˆC\min_\mathbf{x} g(\mathbf{x})\quad s.t. \mathbf{x}\in C xminâ€‹g(x)s.t.xâˆˆC

Where ggg satisfies globally majorant condition:

  1. f(x)â‰¤gk(x),âˆ€xâˆˆCf(\mathbf{x})\le g_k(\mathbf{x}),\forall\mathbf{x}\in Cf(x)â‰¤gkâ€‹(x),âˆ€xâˆˆC
  2. f(xk)=gk(xk)f(\mathbf{x}_k)= g_k(\mathbf{x}_k)f(xkâ€‹)=gkâ€‹(xkâ€‹)

Such that xk+1=argminâ¡xgk(x)âŸ¹f(xk+1)â‰¤gk(xk+1)â‰¤gk(xk)=f(xk)\mathbf{x}_{k+1}=\underset{\mathbf{x}}{\operatorname{argmin}} g_{k}(\mathbf{x}) \Longrightarrow f\left(\mathbf{x}_{k+1}\right) \leq g_{k}\left(\mathbf{x}_{k+1}\right) \leq g_{k}\left(\mathbf{x}_{k}\right)=f\left(\mathbf{x}_{k}\right)xk+1â€‹=xargminâ€‹gkâ€‹(x)âŸ¹f(xk+1â€‹)â‰¤gkâ€‹(xk+1â€‹)â‰¤gkâ€‹(xkâ€‹)=f(xkâ€‹).

Local majorant replace the first requirement with f(xk+1)â‰¤gk(xk+1)f(\mathbf{x}_{k+1})\le g_k(\mathbf{x}_{k+1})f(xk+1â€‹)â‰¤gkâ€‹(xk+1â€‹).

Choice of majorant function#

  • Lipschitz Gradient Surrogate

    gk(x)=f(xk)+âŸ¨âˆ‡f(xk),xâˆ’xkâŸ©+12Î±âˆ¥xâˆ’xkâˆ¥2xk+1=PC(xkâˆ’Î±âˆ‡f(xk))â†projectedÂ gradientÂ descentxk+1=xkâˆ’Î±âˆ‡f(xk),C=Rnâ†gradientÂ descent\begin{aligned} &\begin{array}{c} g_{k}(\mathbf{x})=f\left(\mathbf{x}_{k}\right)+\left\langle\nabla f\left(\mathbf{x}_{k}\right), \mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_{k}\right\rangle+\frac{1}{2 \alpha}\left\|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_{k}\right\|^{2} \\ \mathbf{x}_{k+1}=\mathcal{P}_{\mathcal{C}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{k}-\alpha \nabla f\left(\mathbf{x}_{k}\right)\right) \quad\leftarrow\text{projected gradient descent}\\ \mathbf{x}_{k+1}=\mathbf{x}_{k}-\alpha \nabla f\left(\mathbf{x}_{k}\right),\quad \mathcal{C}=\mathbb{R}^{n}\quad\leftarrow\text{gradient descent} \end{array}\\ \end{aligned} â€‹gkâ€‹(x)=f(xkâ€‹)+âŸ¨âˆ‡f(xkâ€‹),xâˆ’xkâ€‹âŸ©+2Î±1â€‹âˆ¥xâˆ’xkâ€‹âˆ¥2xk+1â€‹=PCâ€‹(xkâ€‹âˆ’Î±âˆ‡f(xkâ€‹))â†projectedÂ gradientÂ descentxk+1â€‹=xkâ€‹âˆ’Î±âˆ‡f(xkâ€‹),C=Rnâ†gradientÂ descentâ€‹â€‹

    Choose Î±\alphaÎ± through backtracking line search. If fff is LLL-smooth, i.e., âˆ¥âˆ‡f(x)âˆ’âˆ‡f(y)âˆ¥â‰¤Lâˆ¥xâˆ’yâˆ¥\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x})-\nabla f(\mathbf{y})\|\le L\|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}\|âˆ¥âˆ‡f(x)âˆ’âˆ‡f(y)âˆ¥â‰¤Lâˆ¥xâˆ’yâˆ¥, then choose Î±=Lâˆ’1\alpha=L^{-1}Î±=Lâˆ’1.

  • Quadratic Surrogate

      EM algorithms minimizes a negative log-likelihood. The right side of this equation can be interpreted as a majorizing surrogate of the left side.

  • Variational Surrogate

    Minimizing a function f(x,y)f(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y})f(x,y) is actually minimizing:

    minâ¡xf(x),Â s.t.Â xâˆˆC,Â whereÂ f(x)=minâ¡yâˆˆYh(x,y)gk(x)=h(x,ykâˆ—),ykâˆ—=argminâ¡yâˆˆYh(xk,y).\min _{\mathbf{x}} f(\mathbf{x}), \quad \text { s.t. } \mathbf{x} \in \mathcal{C}, \quad \text { where } f(\mathbf{x})=\min _{\mathbf{y} \in \mathcal{Y}} h(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}) \\ g_{k}(\mathbf{x})=h\left(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}_{k}^{*}\right), \quad \mathbf{y}_{k}^{*}=\underset{\mathbf{y} \in \mathcal{Y}}{\operatorname{argmin}} h\left(\mathbf{x}_{k}, \mathbf{y}\right) . xminâ€‹f(x),Â s.t.Â xâˆˆC,Â whereÂ f(x)=yâˆˆYminâ€‹h(x,y)gkâ€‹(x)=h(x,ykâˆ—â€‹),ykâˆ—â€‹=yâˆˆYargminâ€‹h(xkâ€‹,y).
